awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Assessing the ecosystem impact of drinking water orthophosphate addition on urban watersheds
awd_abstract_narration:
The city of Pittsburgh is planning to add corrosion inhibitors (e.g., orthophosphate -PO43−), at the end of March 2019 to the 70 million gallons of drinking water (DW) it produces, to combat lead leaching from lead service lines. The planned rate of addition is 2-3 orders of magnitude higher than current levels of reactive phosphorus (P) in DW and urban streams. This substantial change in P concentration, alongside the fact that Pittsburgh's DW pipe network loses an estimated 15 million gallons/day due to leaks, suggests that elevated concentrations of P are likely to infiltrate into groundwater and could ultimately impact the health of urban streams. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project will assess changes in the microbial ecology, water chemistry and nutrient availability in water collected from DW pipes and hydrologically connected urban streams before and after PO43− addition.

The primary goal of this RAPID is to determine whether PO43− addition in the Pittsburgh DW pipe system will impact the ecology and geochemical cycling in hydrologically connected urban streams. Water samples will be collected from urban streams and DW pipe locations eight times before and eight times after PO43− addition. By performing comprehensive water chemistry analysis, microbial community characterization and quantification of specific genera and species linked to PO43− accumulation and nitrogen fixation, the scientists will observe whether broad-scale ecological or nutritional shifts occur. Likewise, algal nutritional limitation studies will provide insight into the eutrophication potential of urban stream water after PO43− addition. Overall, the study will help answer fundamental ecological questions relating to how leaking DW infrastructure can impact nutrient cycling and aquatic ecosystems in hydrologically connected urban streams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The primary goal of this proposal was to establish whether orthophosphate (PO43−) corrosion control addition in the Pittsburgh drinking water (DW) pipe system impacts the ecology and geochemistry cycling in urban streams in an area characterized by failing subsurface water infrastructure.

Results from the study have highlighted that addition of PO43− into the Pittsburgh DW system as a corrosion control chemical can leach into local urban streams through leaking DW or sewer infrastructure. Such introduction of PO43− was found to change the microbial community in the distribution system and resulted in changes in the rare microbial taxa and in some cases impact nutrient cycling in urban streams. Overall, the findings provide further evidence of the subsurface connection between urban streams and urban infrastructure and the complexity involved with ensuring public health safety whilst not impacting environmental safety. Although some changes in nutrient limitation and eutrophication potential were observed it is important to stress that it remains unknown whether these changes are neutral, good or bad and thus future work must continue to examine the environmental impacts of distribution system orthophosphate addition on all hydrologically connected water bodies.

Broader Impacts: This study was the first to the team’s knowledge to simultaneously investigate the impact that large-scale orthophosphate addition has on urban stream chemistry, urban stream microbial ecology, and drinking water microbial communities. The results of this work were incorporated in the undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the PIs. The results were disseminated via multiple conference presentations, invited talks, and journal publications. Overall, results from this study can be applied to other cities which add PO43− to DW, and/or cities which are considering orthophosphate addition in the future. Furthermore, if, as expected, the EPA reduces the lead threshold for drinking water, more cities will likely be forced to take action to reduce lead concentrations by applying corrosion control chemicals such as PO43− thus its presence will likely become even more common in the future. In such cases results from our study can be applied to these cities and can help inform what potential biogeochemical and ecological impacts orthophosphate addition may have to freshwater ecology. The results show that there are ecological changes to the microbial community in the distribution system and impacts to the rarer taxa in hydrologically connected urban streams – however it remains unknown what impact these changes pose.  Based on the results of this study, we recommend pre-treatment testing for up to one year and a longer period of testing following additions.  This will allow for more robust statistical analyses, as well as aid in discerning seasonal trends from treatment effects.
